docs.title: OpenAPI Contract Tester
docs.text:
This project performs live contract testing using an OpenAPI specification as the source of truth.

The OpenAPI spec defines the contract. The running API is tested against it.

If the API and spec diverge, tests fail.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
pip install pytest-openapi
pytest --openapi=http://localhost:8000

docs.title: --openapi=BASE_URL
docs.text: Run contract tests against the API at the specified base URL.

docs.title: --openapi-no-strict-example-checking
docs.text:
Use lenient validation for example-based tests. In this mode, responses are validated for structure and types only, without enforcing exact values or array lengths.

When to use: - Examples contain placeholder or sample data - Dynamic values vary per request (timestamps, IDs, durations) - Array lengths differ from examples in real responses

See Validation Modes for details.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Tests against live APIs
  • ✅ Validates OpenAPI spec quality
  • ✅ Generates test cases from schemas
  • ✅ Hybrid validation (strict + lenient modes)
  • ✅ Supports GET, POST, PUT, DELETE
  • ✅ Readable test reports

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• No authentication handling
  • DELETE tests assume resource existence
  • Schema generation is best-effort
  • No concurrency or performance testing

This tool focuses on correctness, not load or security testing.

docs.title: What is contract testing?
docs.text:
Contract testing verifies that a service behaves exactly as described by its API contract.

In this project: - The contract is the OpenAPI specification - The system under test is a running HTTP API - Tests are executed via real network requests

docs.title: OpenAPI Quality Enforcement
docs.text:
The tool enforces the following rules:

  • Every request body must define:
  • an example OR a schema
  • Every response must define:
  • an example OR a schema
  • Every schema field must include a description

These rules ensure the spec is: - testable - self-documenting - suitable for automation

docs.title: Execution Flow
docs.text:
1. Load OpenAPI specification
  2. Validate spec completeness and quality
  3. Iterate over all paths and HTTP methods
  4. Generate request payloads
  5. Execute live HTTP requests
  6. Compare responses to contract
  7. Record results

docs.title: Path Parameter Resolution
docs.text:
Path parameters are resolved using: - Response examples (id, *_id) - Schema-generated values - Fallback defaults

Example: /users/{user_id} → /users/1

docs.title: Test Case Generation
docs.text:
Test cases are collected from:

  1. Explicit example
  2. Named examples
  3. Generated values from schema

Schema-based generation allows testing even when examples are incomplete or missing.

docs.title: Validation Strategy
docs.text:
pytest-openapi uses different validation approaches depending on the test case origin:

  • Example-based tests: Validated against the example (strict or lenient mode)
  • Schema-generated tests: Always validated against the JSON schema

See Validation Modes for detailed information about strict vs. lenient validation.

docs.title: Opinionated Requirements
docs.text:
pytest-openapi requires:

  • Examples must be present in your OpenAPI spec
  • Responses must include examples (not just schemas)
  • This ensures documentation is complete and useful for consumers

docs.title: Validation Modes
docs.text: pytest-openapi supports two validation strategies depending on the test case origin and user preferences.

docs.title: Hybrid Validation Approach
docs.text: The tool uses a hybrid validation approach that distinguishes between example-based tests and schema-generated tests:

docs.title: Example-Based Tests
docs.text:
When your OpenAPI spec includes explicit request/response examples, pytest-openapi tests these examples against your live API.

Default Behavior (Strict Mode): - Request example → Response must match example exactly - Validates structure, types, and exact values - Array lengths must match - All field values must match

Example: 

responses:
  200:
    content:
      application/json:
        example:
          context: [1, 2, 3]
          total_duration: 1000000000

In strict mode, the actual response must have exactly 3 elements in context and total_duration must be exactly 1000000000.

docs.title: Schema-Generated Tests
docs.text:
When pytest-openapi generates test cases from your schema (not from examples), it always uses schema validation:

  • Validates structure and types only
  • Does not enforce specific values
  • Array lengths are flexible (any length is valid)
  • Only checks that elements match the schema type

This allows broad coverage testing of different input combinations.

docs.title: Lenient Mode for Examples
docs.text:
Sometimes examples contain placeholder values that don't match actual API responses:

example:
  context: [1, 2, 3]  # Placeholder data
  response: "The capital of France is Paris."

But your actual API might return: 

{
  "context": [],  # Empty in real implementation
  "response": "The capital of France is Paris."
}

docs.title: Using --openapi-no-strict-example-checking
docs.text:
Add this flag to use lenient validation for example-based tests:

pytest --openapi=http://localhost:8000 --openapi-no-strict-example-checking

Lenient mode validates: - ✅ All expected keys are present - ✅ Types match (string, number, array, object, etc.) - ✅ Nested structure matches - ✅ Array element types match - ❌ Exact values (ignored) - ❌ Array lengths (ignored)

docs.title: Use Strict Mode (Default) When:
docs.text:
• Your examples accurately reflect real API behavior
  • You want to ensure examples stay synchronized with implementation
  • You're testing documented example interactions

docs.title: Use Lenient Mode When:
docs.text:
• Examples contain placeholder or sample data
  • Array lengths vary in real responses
  • Dynamic values (timestamps, IDs) differ per request
  • You want structural validation without exact value matching

docs.title: Validation Decision Matrix
docs.text: Test Case Origin Example Present? Strict Flag Validation Type Example-based Yes Default (strict) Exact value matching Example-based Yes --no-strict... Structure/type only Schema-generated Any Any Schema validation (always)

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
pytest-openapi is opinionated:

  • Examples are required in your OpenAPI spec
  • This ensures documentation is complete and useful
  • Generated tests provide broad coverage
  • Example tests ensure documented interactions work

The hybrid approach gives you: 1. Confidence that your examples are accurate (strict mode) 2. Flexibility when examples are illustrative (lenient mode) 3. Coverage through schema-generated test cases

docs.title: contract.py
docs.text:
Executes contract tests against a live API.

Includes: - HTTP request execution - GET / POST / PUT / DELETE test logic - Schema-based request/response comparison - Centralized test result logging

docs.title: openapi.py
docs.text:
Responsible for validating the OpenAPI specification.

Key responsibilities: - Ensure request bodies exist - Ensure responses exist - Ensure examples or schemas are present - Ensure all schema fields have descriptions

This module fails fast before any HTTP calls are made.

docs.title: Test Reports
docs.text:
Each test records: - HTTP method - Path - Request body - Expected status and body - Actual status and body - Pass/fail result

A formatted report is generated at the end of execution.
